title: 110_hr3820
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Motor Vehicle Advanced Safety Technology Tax Act of 2007". Congress finds that commercial motor vehicle crashes are a major concern in the United States, especially with the increasing number of trucks and their role in transporting hazardous materials. A 2004 report showed that large truck crashes are more likely to result in fatalities compared to passenger cars. In 2005, there were 5,212 deaths and 114,000 injuries from large truck-related crashes, totaling 25,533 fatalities from 2001 to 2005. These crashes not only result in human loss but also impose a significant economic cost on society. From 2001 to 2005, there were 25,533 large truck-related fatalities in the United States, costing society $230.6 billion annually. Each crash involving a truck over 10,000 pounds has an estimated cost of $91,112, with fatal crashes averaging $3,604,518. Investments in advanced safety systems by vehicle suppliers and manufacturers aim to mitigate commercial motor vehicle crash scenarios. The Department of Transportation has set goals to address these issues. Motorcoach manufacturers have developed advanced safety systems and technologies to address commercial motor vehicle crash scenarios. The Department of Transportation aims to reduce the traffic fatality rate by deploying these technologies. Congress supports increasing the deployment of advanced vehicle safety technologies through tax incentives to make them more affordable for businesses. SEC. 45O. CREDIT FOR COMMERCIAL VEHICLE ADVANCED SAFETY SYSTEMS. This section provides a tax credit for businesses that deploy advanced safety systems in commercial vehicles. The commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit allows a 50% credit for the cost of qualified systems placed in service during the taxable year. Limitations include a maximum credit of $1,500 per system, $3,500 per vehicle, and $350,000 per taxpayer for the year. The term 'qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system' is defined for this purpose. The credit allowable under subsection (a) for the taxpayer for the taxable year shall not exceed $350,000. A qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system includes property part of a system installed on a qualified commercial vehicle, such as brake stroke monitoring, lane departure warning, collision warning, or vehicle stability systems certified by the manufacturer. The taxpayer can claim a credit for a qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system if the system enhances safety, is certified by the manufacturer, and properly installed by an authorized installer. The taxpayer can claim a credit for a qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system if the system is certified by the manufacturer and properly installed by an authorized installer. The qualified commercial vehicle must have a gross combination weight rating or a gross vehicle weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more, or a seating capacity for transporting persons or property in commerce. The section defines criteria for vehicles eligible for certain classifications based on weight, seating capacity, and intended use as a school or intercity/local bus. Additionally, it provides a definition for a brake stroke monitoring system. Additionally, a taxpayer can choose not to take a credit for a qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system. Supporting documentation is required for the credit to be allowed. The qualified commercial vehicle owner must provide supporting documentation as required by the Secretary, including details of the advanced safety system purchased and certifications. The section does not apply to certain properties, and taxpayers have the option to forgo the credit for a qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system. The section outlines requirements for certification and installation of commercial vehicle advanced safety systems. It also amends the general business credit and includes conforming amendments to the tax code.
